awd_abstract_narration:
The Electronic Materials Conference (EMC) is the premier annual forum for the presentation and dissemination of research focused on the preparation, growth, characterization and use of electronic materials. EMC talks, a majority of which are given by students, present cutting-edge research in a wide range of fields, from solar energy materials, metamaterials and plasmonics, quantum structures, electrical and optical characterization techniques, wide bandgap and narrow bandgap materials, nanocomposites, 2D materials, and many others. The design, growth and synthesis, development, and characterization of electronic materials are central to a wide range of scientific fields, from quantum sensing, communication and computation to renewable energy, optical communication and sensing, data storage, power systems, and nano-electronics. EMC provides a unique opportunity for researchers from academia, government labs, and industry to meet and share the latest cutting-edge results across these broad range of fields. While currently drawing from a broad range of disciplines and institutions, EMC is looking to broaden participation of scientists and engineers from minority serving institutions (MSIs), including historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs). This proposal aims to broaden participation in the Electronic Materials Conference by forging close, sustainable ties with MSIs and HBCUs, through the NSF Partnerships for Research and Education in Materials (PREM) program, in order to build a more diverse EMC.

The project is designed to broaden participation in the Electronic Materials Conference (EMC) by building a sustainable relationship between EMC and the NSF Partnerships for Research and Education in Materials program, as well as electronic materials research groups at minority serving institutions (MSIs). The proposed effort will: (i) increase the breadth of research presented at EMC, providing opportunities for dissemination of research results from MSI and HBCU researchers at an impactful forum for electronic materials research, (ii) offer opportunities for networking and the building of collaborative research efforts between MSI researchers and EMC attendees, fostering new research efforts and directions, and (iii) strengthen the EMC by broadening participation in the elected EMC organizing committee and pool of invited organizers. The proposed effort will focus on bringing researchers from MSIs and HBCUs into the EMC fold, both as attendees and presenters, but also as invited organizers and members of the organizing committee. There will also be a focus on reaching out to undergraduate researchers at MSIs, in order to expose these students to a broad range of cutting-edge materials research, inspire these students to continue their education at the graduate level, and thus strengthen the STEM pipeline for under-represented populations. The program will measure success by tracking attendance and participation by MSI and PREM attendees, as well as with a post-conference survey to determine adjustments to EMC that will further help to broaden participation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Electronic Materials Conference (EMC) is the premier annual forum for the presentation and dissemination of research focused on the preparation, growth, characterization and use of electronic materials.  Traditionally, the conference is held annually, with the conference site rotating between a range of Universities, including UC Santa Barbara, Ohio State University, Notre Dame, the University of Michigan, and others.  EMC typically attracts between 350-500 attendees, and consists of an average of 300-350 contributed talks in eight parallel sessions, ~25-50 posters in a single poster session, and a plenary and awards session. 

The design, growth and synthesis, development, and characterization of electronic materials are central to a wide range of scientific fields, from quantum sensing, communication, and computation, to renewable energy, optical communication and sensing, data storage, power systems, and nano-electronics.  EMC provides a unique opportunity for researchers from academia, government labs, and industry to meet and share the latest cutting-edge results across these broad range of fields.  

In the first Broadening Participation program we used the funding from the National Science Foundation to provide registration waivers to participants from Minority Serving Institutions.  As the conference was entirely virtual, we determined this to be the most effective means of lowering barriers to participation from MSI researchers. Registration waivers were awarded to participants from the University of the District of Columbia (6), University of Texas El Paso (6), North Carolina A&T (5), Tuskegee University (3), Hampton University (3), Norfolk State University (2), and other minority serving institutions.  Participants receiving these waivers did not merely attend EMC, but many presented research (as oral presentations or posters) during the conference.  Representative oral presentations included:

-   "Monte Carlo Simulation Study of Single Molecular Spin State Effect on Anti-Ferromagnetically Coupled Magnetic Layers of Magnetic Tunnel Junction Based Spintronics Device"; University of The District of Columbia, United States.

-  "Effect of Biquadratic Coupling Due to Molecular Magnet Channels Between Ferromagnetic Electrodes of a Magnetic Tunnel Junctions"; University of the District of Columbia, United States.

-  "Neutron Diffraction and Transport Properties of Antiferromagnet CaFe2O4,"; Norfolk State University, United States.

-  "Epitaxial GaAsSbN (Te) NWs for Near-Infrared Region Photodetection Application,?; North Carolina A&T State University, United States.

-  "A Te Doped GaAsSb Ensemble Nanowire Photodetector for Near-Infrared Application"; North Carolina A&T State University, United States;  

-  "Effect of Post-Deposition Annealing on the Structure, Morphology and Optical Properties of GeO2 Films"; The University of Texas at El Paso, United States.

We began implementing the above efforts the year before our NSF grant for broadening participation was awarded (EMC 2020).  For EMC 2020, which we identify as Year 0 of our broadening participation plan, we reached out to the PIs of all active PREM programs and invited any student, post-doc, or PI from these institutions to register and attend the (virtual) 2020 EMC with registration fees waived.  Our numbers indicate that 34 students, post-docs and PIs registered and attended EMC in 2020 from PREM or MSI institutions as a result of this initiative (see Table 1).  Their participation greatly increased the diversity of our attendee body: without these attendees, only 6 attendees at EMC 2020 would have been affiliated with Minority Serving Institutions.  In addition, we invited a number of PREM and MSI PIs to join EMC as invited organizers, resulting in three new invited organizers from Minority Serving Institutions: two from the University of Texas El Paso and one from Howard University.

With the NSF Award for EMC 2021, we were able to offer waived registration to all EMC attendees from Minority Serving Institutions who requested waivers.  Though the total attendance of EMC dropped from 549 to 483 attendees from 2020 to 2021, the number of participants from Minority Serving Institutions increased by close to 50%, from 40 to 57 MSI participants.  Thus, as a fraction of total attendees, MSI participation increased from 7% to 11.8%, a substantial increase.  Moreover, it is notable that now close to 11.8% of our attendees are from MSI institutions.

Overall, we consider the effort to broaden participation at the Electronic Materials Conference to be progressing according to plan, despite the challenges posed by initiating such a program in the midst of a global pandemic.  The first year of the program resulted in a significantly more diverse EMC, and the second year of support (to which this funding contributed) saw even larger gains.  With continued support, we believe we can build a self-sustaining relationship with MSI and PREM institutions, in order to cement EMC as a diverse and inclusive conference and the premiere place for the dissemination of research results in electronic materials.

Modified by: Daniel Wasserman
